facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 1007 of 1967 was filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 1007 of 1967. Appeal from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal is from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Bench in Review Application No. 2 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: . Appeal from the judgment and order dated April 30, 1963 of the Allahabad High Court, Lucknow Benc

facts.text: Allahabad High Court granted leave on 21 February 1966.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal is by certificate from the judgment of the Allahabad High Court dated 30 April, 1963. Lea

facts.text: Appellant obtained a decree on 4 October 1939 under the U. P. Encumbered Estates Act, 1934 against Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan for Rs. 1,31,040-1-0 with costs and future interest at 3 1/2 p.a. on the basis of a secured debt.

anchor.surface_text: The facts are these. On 4 October, 1939 the appellant obtained a decree under the U. P. Encumbered Estates Act, 1934 against Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan for the sum of Rs. 1,31,040-1-0 with companyts and future interest at 3 1/2 p.a. on the basis of a secured debt.

facts.text: Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan, the judgment debtor, died on 24 April 1949.

anchor.surface_text: Sardar Mujibul Rahman Khan the judgment debtor died on 24 April, 1949. Thereafter the judgment debtors sons

facts.text: Judgment debtor's sons were brought on record on 21 April 1953.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the judgment debtors sons who were brought on record on 21 April, 1953 applied for reduction

facts.text: Judgment debtor's sons applied for reduction of decretal amount under section 4 of U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 on 24/25 August 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The respondents applied under section 4 of the 1952 Act as it stood prior to its amendment by Act 20 of 1962 on 24/25 August, 1955 in the court of the Special Judge, first-grade, Kheri.

facts.text: Special Judge, Kheri rejected the application on 18 February 1957 holding that unless decree charged mortgaged property no reduction could be ordered.

anchor.surface_text: The application was rejected by the Special Judge, Kheri on 18 February, 1957. The Special Judge held that unless and until the decree charged the mortgaged property no reduction of debt could be ordered under the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 and that the decree was not one such.

facts.text: Judgment debtor filed appeal against Special Judge's order, heard by Full Bench of Allahabad High Court on 27 November 1962, which upheld Special Judge and dismissed appeal treated as revision.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment debtor filed an appeal against the said order of the Special Judge. The appeal was heard on 27 November, 1962 by the Full Bench of the Allahabad High Court upholding the order of the Special Judge and dismissing the appeal which was treated as revision.

facts.text: U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Amendment Act, XX of 1962 received assent of President on 27 November 1962.

anchor.surface_text: Shortly after the dismissal of the revision petition the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 was amended by U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Amendment Act, XX of 1962. The Amendment Act of 1962 received the assent of the President on 27 November 1962

facts.text: Amendment Act published in Gazette on 4 December 1962 and came into force on that date.

anchor.surface_text: which happened to be the date of the order of the High Court on the revision application. The amendment was published in the Gazette on 4 December, 1962 and came, into force on that date.

facts.text: Judgment debtor filed review application on 20 February 1963 against High Court order dated 27 November 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment debtor thereafter on 20 February, 1963 filed an application for review against the order of the Full Bench dated 27th November, 1962.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court accepted review application by majority, set aside Special Judge order, remanded case to Special Judge per amended Act.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court in accordance with the order of the majority accepted the review application of the judgment debtor and set aside the order of the Special Judge rejecting the judgment debtors application under section 4 of the Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 and remanded the case to the Special Judge for disposal of the same in accordance with the provisions of the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 as amended by Act 20 of 1962.

facts.text: Decree relates to a secured debt.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is indisputable that it is a decree relating to secured debt, and the mortgaged property consists of an estate which has been acquired under the provisions of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950.

facts.text: Mortgaged property consists of an estate acquired under U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is indisputable that it is a decree relating to secured debt, and the mortgaged property consists of an estate which has been acquired under the provisions of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950.

facts.text: U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 came into force on 25 May 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The Amendment Act 20 of 1962 which deleted the words charged under the decree occurring in both sub-sections (2) and (3) of section 4 of the 1952 Act immediately after the words mortgaged property was made effective as from the date of enforcement of the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952, namely, 25 May, 1953.

facts.text: Special Judge held decree was not one where mortgaged property was charged under the decree.

anchor.surface_text: The Special Judge held that the decree against the respondents was not one which could be said to be against the mortgaged property charged under the decree.

facts.text: Amendment Act 1962 deleted words 'charged under the decree' from section 4(2) and (3).

anchor.surface_text: The words charged under the decree are shown in brackets only to indicate that these words were deleted by Amendment Act 20 of, 1962.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal.

anchor.surface_text: For these reasons the appeal fails and is dismissed. Each party will pay and bear their own costs.

facts.text: Allahabad High Court in Bannu Mal Ors. v. Bashir Ahmad Khan Ors. held court powerless to reduce debts unless mortgaged property charged under decree.

anchor.surface_text: The reason for this amendment given in the objects and reasons of the U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Amendment Act, 1962 was because the High Court of Allahabad in the case, of Bannu Mal Ors. v. Bashir Ahmad Khan Ors. held that the court was powerless to reduce debts after the passing of the decree unless the mortgaged property was charged under the decree.

facts.text: Amendment Act provides it has effect as if in force on all material dates from enforcement of 1952 Act, except discharged debts.

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the amendment of the 1952 Act is embodied in section 2 of the Amendment Act, 1962 which is as follows The U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 shall as to the date of this enforcement have effect subject to the amendments made by this Act as if this Act had been in force on all material dates Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a debt which has been discharged prior to the date of enactment of this Act.

arguments.claim: Section 2 of Amendment Act deems 1952 Act amended as if in force on all material dates from its enforcement except discharged debts

anchor.surface_text: The effect of the amendment of the 1952 Act is embodied in section 2 of the Amendment Act, 1962 which is as follows The U. P. Zamindars Debt Reduction Act, 1952 shall as to the date of this enforcement have effect subject to the amendments made by this Act as if this Act had been in force on all material dates Provided that nothing in this section shall apply to a debt which has been discharged prior to the date of enactment of this Act.

arguments.claim: Full effect must be given to deeming fiction carrying it to logical conclusion as per State of Bombay v. Pandurang Vinayak Chaphalkar

anchor.surface_text: The effect of such a deeming clause was stated by this Court in State of Bombay v. Pandurang Vinayak Chaphalkar Ors. (1) as follows When a statute enacts that something shall be deemed to have been done, which in fact and truth was not done, the court is entitled to ascertain for what purposes and between what persons the statutory fiction is to be resorted to and full effect must be given to the statutory fiction and it should be carried to its logical conclusion.

arguments.claim: Deeming provision means words 'charged under the decree' were never in section 4(2); only requirement is mortgaged property consists of acquired estate

anchor.surface_text: These observations indicate that the words charged under the decree in section 4 (2) of the 1952 Act were never there with the inevitable consequence that the only statutory requirement is whether the mortgaged property consists of estate which has been acquired under the provisions of the U. P. Zamindari Abolition and Land Reforms Act, 1950.

arguments.claim: Applying pre-amendment law when deeming provision made amended law applicable from 1953 constitutes error apparent on face of record warranting review under Order 47 CPC

anchor.surface_text: The result is that the Court is to apply the legal provision as it always stood. It would, therefore, be error on the face of the record. The error would be that the law that was applied was not the law which is applicable.

arguments.claim: Section 4 confers power notwithstanding CPC; substance not form of review application decisive; treat as application under section 4

anchor.surface_text: Secondly, section 4 of the 1952 Act confers power on the court to apply the law notwithstanding any provision contained in the Code of Civil Procedure. Therefore the application though intituled an application for review was not be so. The substance and not the form of the application will be decisive.

arguments.claim: 1952 Act is special legislation conferring benefits on judgment debtors like respondents in special jurisdiction notwithstanding CPC

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, it is a preeminent consideration to be kept in the forefront that the 1952 Act was amended to confer benefit on judgment debtors of the type of the respondents. This is a special legislation conferring rights and reliefs within a specially created jurisdiction.
